@zliu41 actually I just realized using a plain integer has one problem: the `getApplicationReportFailureCount` is shared and updated in both event handlers `handleApplicationReportArrivalEvent` and `handleGetApplicationReportFailureEvent`, which may be called by different threads. So for any change to `getApplicationReportFailureCount` in any of the two event handlers to be visible to the other, it at least needs to be `volatile`. So I still think `AtomicInteger` is a good choice here and it offers more than `volatile` with thread safety.
Yay!!!!
Merging since this is a mechanical change and build passes.
Why not inject the final tag in the `ScheduledReporter`?

There may be other implementations of `ScheduledReporter` that want to do something else on the final report. Plus, the fact that we need to tag the final report is specific to `MetricReportReporter` because it is reporting metrics.

@ibuenros updated. `MetricTypeFilter` now takes in a `List` of `Metrics` rather than regex.

Actually, for metric type, it might be easier to do the filtering in the `ScheduledReporter` itself. The `report` method calls `report(counters, meters, ...)`, so for each argument you could have a switch statement 
`report(metricTypesToReport.contains(Counter) ? context.getCounters(this.filter) : new ArrayList<>(), ...)`.

Is there a benefit to doing the filtering in `ScheduledReporter` itself vs. using `MetricFilter`? The advantage of the current approach is that all metric filtering is done through a single interface, `MetricFilter`.
LGTM other than minor comments.
LGTM

It is more efficient (check only once per metric type, instead of checking every single metric), and imo easier to understand, but that's debatable.
The other approach is fine. Just a suggestion, instead of doing string comparison, consider using class comparison (e.g. `metric instanceof Counter`).

Few general comments:

1: Can you squash all your commits into a single commit (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5189560/squash-my-last-x-commits-together-using-git)
2: Can you remove all mentions of "GaaP" so that this code is not tied to a specific proxy - you should just be able to make it a configuration option (like `user.agent.name` or something along those lines)
3: Is there a more detailed design doc on how this all works?
4: Adding more javadocs to the `Tunnel.java` class would be very helpful, and consider breaking the `Tunnel.java` class down into multiple classes as it is pretty long.
5: If you could follow the Gobblin coding style guide that would be great (https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/wiki/CodingStyle)
Thanks for the comments, will incorporate the feedback.

@kunalkandekar just one more comment: Gobblin is not using the standard LinkedIn coding style so none of our classes use variable names starting with `_`. Check it out here https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/wiki/CodingStyle.
Really simple fix, self approved.
@kadaan I just briefly went through the code and commented mostly on the syntax/style aspects. I will need a bit more time to go over this and PR #569 again to understand the overlap. Stay tuned.

@liyinan926 AFAIK, #569 doesn't really address these issues.  The underlying problem here is that currently publishing can "succeed" and the files don't actually make it to the publish location.  With this issue gobblin doesn't even ensure "at least once" publishing of the data.  #569 adds the concept of "exactly once" publishing, but I feel that "at least once" should be working correctly before adding more complexity.
@kadaan got it. Yes, that's a bug that needs to be fixed.
@liyinan926 I detailed this issue in #561.  Also, this issue is exacerbated when you publish to S3 as the directory cannot be moved in one shot (unlike HDFS).

We generally try to have 1 commit per new feature in Gobblin. This way we can have a single, descriptive commit message describing the change.

Main comments around documentation and some refactor. Like @sahilTakiar said please squash the commits and update the pr.
Here are the steps

git rebase -i HEAD~num_commits_to_squash
An editor will show up where you can squash/pick commits
git push upstream master --force

Users that try to compile with cdh releases get compilation errors, and a fix has been going around the user list involving adding the cloudera repository to all gradle projects.
This PR fixes the build for cdh releases.
@chavdar , please review the RB for caching layer of ConfigStore.getConfig
@sahilTakiar @ydai1124 @vasanthrajamani can you review?

@kadaan previously `publishMultiTaskData` has the option of moving the entire task output folder at once (if `data.publisher.replace.final.dir=true`). Now this option seems to be gone, and it always moves each file individually. Even with `ParallelRunner`, this could be a lot slower.

I'm thinking of adding that option back. When using that option, since there is only a single `rename` operation for each branch, we don't use `ParallelRunner` (hence no inconsistency issue) but move the folder synchronously in the publisher. What do you think?

@zliu41 It really is filesystem specific as to how the move can be done.  If you are moving from HDFS to the _same_ HDFS, then renaming the folder is fine.  As soon as you are doing any other kind of move (local -> HDFS, local -> S3, etc.) then the rename is an issue.  The problem really is that the rename is a hadoop filesystem call and what it does underneath is hidden from gobblin.  For instance, when the filesystem is HDFS then it can just rename the folder.  However, when the filesystem is S3, it needs to walk the directory tree and and upload each file individually.  

Really, what is needed is different code paths for the different filesystems.  That way we could do an atomic folder copy for HDFS and update all WorkUnitStates when done.  For the S3 filesystem we could move the folder like I have done in this PR and update the WorkUnitStates while moving.  The problem with this approach is that it doesn't extend to new filesystems.  

Alternatively, like you have suggested, we could add a flag to control whether we publish the folder as one atomic unit or walk the folder and upload the contents individually.  The issue with adding this flag is that if the S3 filesystem is used then the we basically require that the folder is uploaded by walking the structure. If this setting is missed or forgotten, then we cannot guarantee "at least once" semantics.

_The method in this PR will work for all hadoop filesystems._ 

I understand your concern for performance, but can you quantify the performance hit this would cause?  Also, can you please specify the expected size of a folder that is being published so we have a common benchmark to use for comparison?

@zliu41 @liyinan926 As this seems to be a pretty high priority issue, I'd like to see if we could hash out a solution in a more interactive method.  What do you think about discussing this in IRC. I've setup a gobblin channel on Freenode and can add all of you guys as admins if this seems acceptable.
@chavdar Can you review?

@kadaan sounds good. I haven't used freenode before, is it like a chatroom? Let me know how it should be used.

Actually it could be slower even if `data.publisher.replace.final.dir=false`, because previously, `addWriterOutputToExistingDir` doesn't walk the directory tree, but only does a `listStatus` and moves each file and subfolder directly under the task output folder to the publisher output folder. Now if we always moves files individually, I guess all jobs using `publishMultiTaskData` will suffer.
@zliu41 Can you review this?
@zliu41 I added a badge for the IRC channel to the readme in this PR: #609.  Freenode is an IRC network.  You should just be able to click the IRC badge on the readme.

I'd really love to be able to quantify what the performance loss would be for HDFS.  For S3, there should be zero performance loss as internally the S3AFileSystem was walking the directory tree and uploading each file individually.
@chavdar  what do you think?
LGTM
